title: John Batchelor Aug 23 Day After Trump.mp3
description:
What Happens to the Republicans the Day After Trump? @jamestaranto, @opinionjournal.

â€œâ€¦This column rejects the premise that Trump is certain to lose, although weâ€™ll concede that on current evidence he is likelier than not to do so. But lately another question has been preoccupying us: If Trump does lose, can the Republican Party survive?

Will seemed to think so back in April, when he claimed that if Trump loses big, â€œRepublicans working to purge him and his manner from public life will reap the considerable satisfaction of preserving the identity of their 162-year-old party.â€ Will himself publicly rejected that identity two months later, telling PJMedia he was no longer a Republican. But anyway our question isnâ€™t about whether the Republican â€œidentityâ€ can survive; itâ€™s whether the party can.

A basic function of a political party is to unify behind a nominee, and the GOP has conspicuously failed to do so this year. In the first debate, in August 2015, the most memorable moment not involving Rosie Oâ€™Donnell came when moderator Bret Baier called for a show of hands: â€œIs there anyone on stage . . . who is unwilling tonight to pledge your support to the eventual nominee of the Republican party and pledge to not run an independent campaign against that person? . . . Raise your hand now if you wonâ€™t make that pledge tonightâ€ (emphasis ours)â€¦.â€
